name: Europe threatens legal action over AstraZeneca vaccine supplies
introduction: The latest chapter in an ongoing saga over European supplies of AstraZenecaâs coronavirus vaccine looks likely to involve legal action.
content:
The latest chapter in an ongoing saga over European supplies of AstraZeneca’s (LSE: AZN) coronavirus vaccine looks likely to involve legal action.

The European Commission is reportedly asking the 27 EU member states to back litigation against the British firm, which it says is in breach of contractual obligations to supply the product, Vaxzevria.

AstraZeneca has said it inked a so-called “best efforts” contract with Europe, and that supply chain disruptions prevented it from supplying the estimated amount.

While Europe has received just 30 million doses, the UK has used an exclusive arrangement with the drugmaker, agreed early on in development of the product, to vaccinate a far larger share of its population.

Long-running dispute

With the vaccine rollout in Europe proceeding slowly, officials threatened to block vaccine exports in February, raising concerns over “vaccine nationalism.”

The EU has said AstraZeneca should divert supplies from its UK supply chain to fulfill what it sees as a legal obligation to provide more.

With tensions rising, the UK and EU agreed in March to discuss “what more we can do to ensure a reciprocally beneficial relationship between the UK and EU on COVID-19.”

Those discussions appear not to have dissuaded the EU from pursuing a hard line on the matter. The trading bloc is counting on receiving 70 million vaccine doses from AstraZeneca in the second quarter of 2021.

Vaccine safety monitoring

While the EU fights to secure supplies of AstraZeneca’s vaccine, which was first approved by the UK regulator in December 2020, several countries have restricted its use to older populations amid concerns over a rare side effect of blood clotting.

Scientists are unclear whether a small number of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) cases are linked to the use of the viral vector-based product, partly due to uncertainty over how widespread the rare condition is among the general population.

In an update on Thursday, the UK’s medicines regulator, the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), said it had found 168 major blood clots following a dose of Vaxzevria - equal to 7.9 clots per million doses.

There have been over 20 million doses of the product given in the UK, and public health authorities around the world have confirmed the vaccine to be safe and effective.

In a statement, the MHRA said: "On the basis of this ongoing review, the advice remains that the benefits of the vaccine outweigh the risks in the majority of people.”

The agency has, however, recommended that people under 30 be offered an alternative type of vaccine.
